Graphical abstract This work aims to disclose the support-substrate interaction and surface dynamics in heterogeneous catalysis by an original Low Field 2D NMR relaxation in complement to previous High Field NMR relaxometry. The combination of High Field NMR measurements with the new Low Field 2D NMR results presented in this work confirmed the possibility to extract information on local molecular dynamics and 2D surface dynamics for the complex system of aldehyde hydrogenation on Pd/C catalysts in the presence of a solvent. In particular, here multidimensional Low Field (2D) 1H nuclear magnetic relaxation experiments (T1-T2) have been used to characterize noninvasively the dynamical properties of benzaldehyde, octanal and p-xylene at surfaces of Pd-supported on carbon catalysts. 2D Low Field 1H NMR relaxation is sensitive to the environment of the reactant molecules and gives unambiguous information on the surface dynamics of the molecule; the association with previous 13C NMR relaxation at High Field s allows comparison between molecular orientations and local surface dynamics at surface of catalysts. In heterogeneous catalysis these new experimental and theoretical multiscale approaches link interfacial molecular dynamics and interaction with catalytic materials. This point is critical for disentangle chemical from physical reactant adsorption and deepening the role of the support material and its physical features in catalytic processes. Keywords Reactant-catalyst interactions NMR relaxation Low and high field relaxation T1-T2 correlation maps Heterogeneous catalyst Surface dynamics Catalytic hydrogenation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction 1.1 High field 13C NMR relaxometry as a structural tool for interactions After excitation by a radiofrequency wave, nuclei in a magnetic field will produce a decaying signal while exchanging energy with their environment via different mechanisms. The nuclei of a molecule will exchange energy with the surface of a catalyst upon adsorption, whereas only exchanges between nuclei occur in the liquid bulk, the latter process being less efficient than the first. Therefore, the study of Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) signal decay or relaxation (relaxometry) gives insight of the molecules’ dynamics and interactions with the catalyst surface. The NMR measurement of 13C longitudinal relaxation time (T1) can be used to disclose important aspects of a catalytic reaction, as we demonstrated in a very recent work [1]. In particular, a Pd supported on carbon catalyst (Pd/C) has been used for the hydrogenation of aldehydes in liquid phase, showing a very different activity depending on the substrate. Indeed, Pd/C showed high activity towards benzaldehyde hydrogenation, while no activity toward n-octanal hydrogenation [2]. Both reactions were performed using an aromatic solvent (p-xylene), classically chosen because of its high boiling point and because it does not convolute the analysis of by-products such as toluene. By High Field 13C NMR analyses, we measured the relaxation time T1 of each carbon atom of the organic molecules involved in the reaction. In particular, the T1bulk was measured without the catalyst, while the T1ads was measured after suspending the catalyst powder in the solution. The strength of interaction between the carbon atoms of the reactant molecule and the catalyst surface can be associated with the T1ads/T1bulk ratio, as the lower the T1ads/T1bulk the higher the interaction. The measured T1ads/T1bulk values showed a stronger adsorption of the aromatic aldehyde compared to the solvent, in contrast with the aliphatic aldehyde which was not adsorbed because of the competitive adsorption of the solvent. Such competition was the key factor limiting the catalytic reaction. However, the results obtained from High Field NMR are sometimes difficult to interpret. The decrease in T1 can be considered as a proof of restricted mobility [3], which results from the interaction with the catalyst surface. However, an invariable T1 (T1ads very similar to T1bulk) is not always a proof of absence of such interactions. Indeed, by High Field 13C NMR we can collect information mostly on local molecular dynamics and not on the overall adsorption of the reactant molecule thus not always correlated with the catalytic activity. Moreover, some carbon atoms are more sensitive to relaxation variations from surface interactions than others are: for example, the lack of freedom in the motions of sp2 hybridized carbons (aromatic carbons or carbonyls) induces more easily anisotropy in the molecule’s motions compared to sp3, this anisotropy being a fundamental contribution to the NMR relaxation processes of 13C. 1.2 Low field 1H NMR relaxometry as quantifying tool for interactions and molecular surface dynamics These phenomena can be captured by Low Field 2D T1-T2 NMR relaxation which is known to access information on surface dynamics [4]. The ratio between T1 and T2 has been used in NMR spectroscopy as a probe for the molecule-surface interaction both in high and Low Field NMR, since the decrease in T2 is more pronounced from the interaction with the catalyst. However, the measurement of T2 is affected by some interference in High Field NMR [5] and the measurement of T1bulk/T1ads can be preferred [1]. Low Field 1H NMR relaxation is sensitive to the environment of the molecular probe. Usually, in porous media, the unique source of relaxation comes from the fluctuation of the dipole-dipole interaction between the immobile paramagnetic species at the surface and the translational diffusion of the protonated molecule; therefore, 1H Low Field NMR analyses could provide unambiguous information on the surface dynamics of the probed molecule. The study of surface interactions by Low Field 1H NMR Relaxometry has been performed on rock cores for several years [6]. Using appropriate theoretical motion modelling, it is possible to extract from the measurement of the macroscopic longitudinal (T1) and transverse (T2) relaxation times quantitative information on the molecular surface dynamics. Specifically, microscopic correlation times such as the residence time (τS) and the correlation time (τm) between two immediate successive relocations on the same surface. The residence time (τS) is the time between the arrival of the molecule on the surface and its definitive departure from it (on the time scale of T1). The correlation time (τm) is inversely proportional to the translational surface diffusion coefficient. The model assumes a unique average τm for all surface displacement, however there can be several τS, each being represented by a T1-T2 crosspeak on the processed data figure. The existence of several crosspeaks, thus τS, can then be related to various assumptions on the interaction they represent. For instance, they can be regarded as the existence of as many types of interaction sites, or the ability of the molecular probe to interact with the surface only with specific conformations or approach vectors. Once on the surface, as depicted on Fig. 1 , the molecule would move for τS time from one position to another taking τm time in average for each motion. The two microscopic correlation times provide direct information on the affinity of the molecule for the surface of a catalyst, which is representative of the microscopic dynamical variables such as translational correlation times and diffusion coefficients. Many theoretical models exist in the literature for bulk liquids that relate T1 and T2 to these dynamical variables [7,8]. However, in the case of liquids embedded in porous media, such as catalytic materials suspended in the reaction solution, the conditions are more complex due to the presence of surface relaxation processes in addition to the bulk ones. At Low Field, although there is no access to individual 1H NMR signals due to the absence of resolution, it is possible to measure the two-dimensional (2D) spin correlation spectrum T1-T2 at a given Larmor frequency. Here, an original mixed inversion recovery-FID-CPMG sequence was used at 20 MHz, enhancing the time scales studied (0.1 ms−3 s) to generate 2D T1-T2 correlation data. The final map has been then obtained with an in house 2-D Inverse Laplace Transform program. Applying this 2D NMR technique to carbon-based catalysts impregnated with aldehydes liquid solutions, it was possible to obtain helpful information on the behaviour of the organic molecules interacting with the catalytic surface. Referring to the previously proposed parametric relaxation equations for T1 and T2 for liquids at proximity of a solid surface [9,10], the proposed model is mainly based on the biphasic fast exchange between the bulk and the surface contributions of the relaxation rates 1/T1 and 1/T2. The hypothesis is that the time for a molecule to exchange between the bulk and the surface is sensibly lower than the minimal T1 or T2. For the surface relaxation contributions to these rates, the proton-liquid dynamics modulates the intermolecular dipole-dipole interaction between the moving proton of spins I = 1/2 and the fixed S = 1/2 paramagnetic spins of paramagnetic C radicals at the pore surface. These surface relaxation rates depend mainly on two correlation times (Fig. 1) [9]: (i) the translational surface diffusion correlation time (τm), that considers the successive molecular hopping time at the pore surface. This correlation time being inversely proportional to the translational surface diffusion coefficient (ii) the surface residence time (τs), which is much larger than τm. The dynamical surface affinity can be estimated by the ratio A=τs/τm that represents the average number of molecular steps on the pore surface. This parameter thus represents the local NMR wettability. The differences in τs and τm can be more readily interpreted than T1 and T2, as they represent directly molecular surface dynamical information. Hereafter, 1H 2D T1-T2 Low Field NMR relaxation and 13C High Field NMR are considered as complementary analyses of respectively local molecular dynamics and surface dynamics which, when combined, provide a much more complete picture of the interaction between a molecule and the surface of a catalyst. In particular, in this work 2D T1-T2 Low Field NMR relaxation was used in addition to 13C High Field NMR relaxometry, comparing all experimental data to molecular model and to theoretical motions model simulations [6]. Complementary to the data obtained by High Field NMR the interaction of an aliphatic (n-octanal) and aromatic (benzaldehyde) aldehydes with a carbon-based catalyst (Pd/C) was studied here by Low Field NMR. The present study of the interaction between such substrates and the carbon-based catalyst by Low Field NMR relaxation aimed to improve the information got by 13C High Field NMR, obtaining an estimation of the dynamical surface affinity (by the ratio τs/τm); these surfaces dynamical information could be used to determine possible interactions that are favourable to catalysis, which finally cannot be gathered only by T1 measurements in High Field NMR. 2 Experimental 2.1 NMR data acquisition and processing The NMR Low Field experiments were carried out on Bruker Minispec MQ20 spectrometer at 20 MHz proton carrier frequency with a 10 mm diameter probe. The pulse lengths for 90° and 180° pulses were 2 and 5 µs. The relaxation delay varied depending on the sample relaxation T1 time. The 2D T1-T2 maps have been acquired using inversion recovery sequence followed by FID-CMPG sequence with zero delay between them. FID prefix for CPMG sequence means that the free induction decay (FID) part was acquired prior to echo measurement to gain higher precision by measuring early experimental points. The acquisition is performed only in the FID-CPMG part. The measurements have been done at 303 K if not specified differently. The obtained data have been post-processed using Inverse Laplace Transform (ILT, homemade Matlab program made by J.-P. Korb following an algorithm published in ref. [11]) to get 2D T1-T2 maps. The T2/T1 ratios have been manually measured directly on the 2D map. The NMR experiments were performed on pure substrates and in the presence of the catalyst. In this case the NMR tube was filled with 40 mg of the powder sample and 40 μl of pure or diluted substrate after 30 min for temperature and filling stabilization. 2.2 Synthesis of the Pd/C catalyst Na2PdCl4 (≥99.99%, Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA) was used as Pd precursor, NaBH4 (powder, ≥98.0% Sigma Aldrich) as reducing agent and Poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) (Mw 9000–10,000, 80% hydrolysed, Sigma Aldrich) as protecting agent. The carbon used as support was xGnP® (purchased by XG Sciences Inc., Lansing, MI, USA). The synthesis was performed by sol-immobilization [12]. Briefly, to an aqueous solution of Na2PdCl4 (0.5 mmol L−1) kept under constant stirring, a PVA solution (1% wt.) with a PVA-to-metal weight ratio of 0.5 was added first. Then, an aqueous solution of NaBH4 (NaBH4-to-metal molar ratio of 8) was added to reduce the metal ion to Pd0 and form metal nanoparticles. After 30 min, the colloid was immobilized by adding the carbon support and acidified at pH 2 by sulfuric acid under continuous vigorous stirring. A metal loading of 1% wt. was targeted. After 1 h of stirring, the slurry was filtered, washed and dried at 80 °C for 2 h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Elemental analysis was carried out with a PerkinElmer CHN 2400 instrument. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analyses were carried out on a FEI Tecnai F20 microscope in order to evaluate the Pd nanoparticle sizes. The instrument was equipped with a Field Emission Gun (FEG) and operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Samples were prepared by sonication of the sample in isopropanol followed by deposition on 300-mesh copper grids coated with lacey carbon film. Histograms of the particle size distribution (PSD) were obtained by counting at least 500 particles. The mean particle diameter (dm) was calculated using the formuladm = ∑ dini/ni, where ni is the number of particles with diameter di. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were acquired in an M-probe apparatus (Surface Science Instruments) equipped with an atmospheric reaction chamber. The XPS line of Pd3d was recorded by applying an AlKα characteristic X-ray line and (hν = 1486.6 eV) pass energy. All data were analyzed using CasaXPS (Casa Software, v2.3.17 PR1.1). 2.4 Catalytic tests The reference catalysts (Pd/C) were tested in the hydrogenation of benzaldehyde (ReagentPlus®, ≥99% Sigma-Aldrich) and octanal (for synthesis, Sigma-Aldrich). The reactions were carried out in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave, using 10 mL of a 0.3 M solution of substrate (benzaldehyde or octanal) in p-xylene (anhydrous, ≥99% Sigma-Aldrich) and an amount of catalyst corresponding to a reactant-to-metal molar ratio of 1000:1. The hydrogenation of benzaldehyde was performed at 50 °C and 2 bar of H2 pressure, the hydrogenation of octanal at 120 °C and 20 bar of H2. Samplings were carried out by stopping the stirrer and quenching the reaction under cold water. The catalyst was separated from the reaction medium for GC measurement, carried out through a GC-FID equipped with a non-polar column (Thermo Scientific, TRACE 1300 equipped with an Agilent HP-5 column) using 1-dodecanol in p-xylene as external standard. 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst characterization and catalytic behaviour The commercial carbon used as support was xGnP®. It has a BET surface area of 500 m2 g−1 and total pore volume of 0.84 mL g−1. The elemental CHON analysis and XPS analyses were performed on the bare carbon to determine its composition (Table 1 ) and extent of oxygen functionalization (Table 2 ). Fig. 2 shows the TEM characterization of the 1% Pd/C. The Pd nanoparticles are homogeneously distributed on the carbon support and exhibit a dm of 3.5 nm. As already reported in [1], the Pd/C was effective in benzaldehyde hydrogenation to benzyl alcohol and further hydrogenolysis to toluene, using p-xylene as solvent and working at 50 °C and 2 bar of H2. In the case of n-octanal hydrogenation, the catalyst was very poorly active (conversion <3%) when using p-xylene as solvent, while the conversion increased to 40 % by changing the solvent from p-xylene to n-dodecane. This different behaviour was reflected in 13C High Field NMR results: the T1ads/T1 bulk ratio values measured for the C atoms of n-octanal in the presence of p-xylene and Pd/C were always close to 1 (indicating scarce or absent interaction). On the contrary, the T1ads/T1 bulk ratio values measured for the C atoms of n-octanal in the presence of n-dodecane and Pd/C were below 0.9, thus indicating a restricted mobility of octanal on the Pd/C surface at those conditions. We attributed the invariability of the T1 of n-octanal in the presence of the catalyst and p-xylene to the stronger adsorption of p-xylene, which prevented the adsorption of n-octanal on the catalyst surface and thus its conversion. 3.2 Relaxation of bulk chemicals The Low Field NMR analyses of the pure substrates, i.e. benzaldehyde and n-octanal were performed to determine the bulk T1 and T2 relaxation times (note that in bulk non-viscous liquids T1 is equal to T2). These relaxation times are supposed to be altered when the reactant molecule is contacted with the catalyst (impregnation). Unfortunately the very long relaxation time of pure benzaldehyde cannot be measured by our systems but value of approximately 6 s has already been reported in literature [13]. However, the n-octanal bulk relaxation times were measured. We considered only the most intense peak to calculate the T1 and T2, the others probably being affected by the artefacts of inverse Laplace Transform (ILT). As expected, we obtained equal values of T1 and T2 of about 2.1 s. Accordingly, there is no confinement in the bulk n-octanal. 3.3 Relaxometry on impregnated bare carbon support NMR analyses of benzaldehyde and n-octanal (Fig. 3 ) in the presence of bare carbon support were performed to determine the adsorption T1 and T2 relaxation times. The first notable, and expected, result, is the decrease for both substrates of their T1 and T2 values by several orders of magnitude in the latter case (see Table 3 for precise values). Both molecules should be able to diffuse freely through the carbon support pore system as BET analyses show a mesoporous structure which assured the absence of diffusion limits (Table 1). Based on the T1-T2 maps (Fig. 4 ), benzaldehyde and n-octanal exhibit different correlation spectra in their 2D T1-T2 maps. The benzaldehyde shows mainly one type of adsorption (centered at T1/T2 = 19.3) (Fig. 4a) whereas the n-octanal distribution is elongated indicating a wide distribution of different adsorption modes with a center at T1/T2 = 22.7 (Fig. 4b). In porous materials, the T2 and T1 relaxation times are known to depend on confinement geometry [2]. They are reduced in narrow pores compared to the bulk (remind that in bulk non viscous liquids T2 = T1 [2]. Therefore, the different pore filling rate should alter both distributions of T1 and T2 relaxation times due to partial filling of pores (reduced dynamics) and preferential filling of smaller pores at low saturation rate. In order to verify the biphasic (adsorbed-bulk) fast exchange condition, we have performed T1-T2 experiments with variable volumes of substrates. 3.3.1 Influence of benzaldehyde filling rate The T1-T2 maps of carbon support impregnated with (a) 20 µl, (b) 50 µl and (c) 100 µl of benzaldehyde are reported in Fig. 4. Looking at the T1-T2 maps (Fig. 4), it is possible to observe some phenomena occurring with increasing the amount of benzaldehyde: • T1 and T2 of crosspeaks increase (see also Table 4 ) • The second bigger crosspeak in the 20 µl experiment disappears at 50 µl • The curvature of the main crosspeak at 20 µl disappears at 50 µl. The intensity scale has been adapted for each figure. Accordingly, the intensity of the peak in the experiment with 100 µl of benzaldehyde is twice as the one with 50 µl and 4.5 times the one with 20 µl. The increase of the amount of the substrate, and it is particularly noticeable in the passage from 20 to 50 µl, allows the presence of more and more layers of solvent at the surface of the catalyst. Hence, facilitating the passage from of interaction site to another, i.e., a more bulk-like behavior for the solvent. Also, the increase of T1 and T2 values with increase of added volume agrees with the molecules filling bigger pores and as such their behavior get closer to bulk. One could have expected the signals of the experiments with 20 µl and 50 µl of benzaldehyde to be part of the signal with 100 µl. However, the signal of the molecules in the bigger pores hides the signal of those in the smaller ones. As such, our ILT algorithm is not able to distinguish them because the signal intensities of the latter are too low. According to calculations, shown herein before approximately 38 µl of benzaldehyde is enough to saturate the pore volume. The T1/T2 values tend to decrease with increasing amount of benzaldehyde that is in accordance with the thesis work mention before [3]. The adsorption of 20 µl has T1/T2 ratio of 28.2, 50 µl is 29.8, and 100 µl has the lowest value of 26.5, therefore there is very little variation. We will see in the theoretical section that all these observations will be consistent with the verification of the biphasic fast exchange conditions. 3.3.2 Influence of n-octanal filling rate As in the case of benzaldehyde, the carbon support has been impregnated by 20 and 50 µl of octanal. 2D T1-T2 maps are reported in Fig. 5 . Increasing the amount of substrate, the distribution of the signal on the maps, which is extending along a curve, switched from two distinct modes to a larger continuous one, with a small shoulder on the left. Considering the total pore volume of the carbon support (equal to 38 μl), we can suppose that with 50 μl of n-octanal we start observing motions in larger pores. Consequently, we rather observe an extension of the distribution more than its translation. The additional molecules would mostly be present in larger pores leading to higher T1 and T2 as confirmed from the results in Table 5 . Considering the last signal (s5, named the maxima), the increase of the T1/T2 ratio from 29 to 37 could indicate only a small variation in affinity. Comparing the results obtained with benzaldehyde and n-octanal, the most obvious difference relates to the distribution of the peaks in the 2D T1-T2 maps. Indeed, in the case of n-octanal we observed a continuous distribution of peaks along a master curve, while using benzaldehyde different peaks were obtained only using different filling ratios. The continuous distribution of the peaks showed in the n-octanal 2D maps can be an indication of more modes of interaction with the surface than benzaldehyde has. The filling rate of the porous material is of outmost importance. It is clear that study of such material with the presented methodology requires to run several experiments with various volumes of substrate to have a complete comprehension of the interactions at the surface. Corollary, the comparisons of two porous material should also take in account this parameter. 3.4 Relaxometry with Pd/C The 2D T1-T2 map of Pd/C impregnated with 50 μl of pure benzaldehyde displayed multiple peaks compared to bare carbon (Fig. 6 ). The calculated T1/T2 ratios are reported in Table 6 . Pd presence changed the overall shape of the signals in the 2D T1-T2 map: this variation can be interpreted as the creation of additional adsorption sites compared to pure carbon. However, the strength of interactions would be comparable within the limit of experimental error (24.7 versus 23.1, Table 6). Despite the rather low intensities of the peaks, they have not been considered as artifacts, as they play a crucial role in determining the overall curve shape. It can be also claimed that the addition of Pd seems to have created new interaction sites with reduced strength compared to bare carbon due to the appearance of additional peaks having lower T1/T2 ratios (Table 7 ). The 2D T1-T2 maps of bare carbon (a) and Pd/C (b) impregnated with 50 µl of n-octanal are reported in Fig. 7 . In this case, the comparison between the bare and the Pd-supported catalyst showed sensitive changes. While in the case of bare carbon (Fig. 7a), we could observe mostly a continuous map of adsorption, in the presence of Pd nanoparticles (Fig. 7b) several distinct modes with different areas are clearly distinguishable. Moreover, when n-octanal is measured in the presence of Pd/C the signal distribution is more compact compared to the one obtained with bare carbon. The net change of the form of the distribution of T1-T2 (continuous vs discrete) thus gives a clear indication of the nature of the conformational adsorption sites. T1/T2 values calculated for Pd/C impregnated with pure n-octanal are reported in Table 8 . Compared to the results obtained on bare carbon, it seems that the addition of Pd nanoparticles on the carbon surface results in the formation of new interaction modes, both in the case of benzaldehyde and n-octanal. However, the new interaction mode formed in the presence of n-octanal was stronger than with benzaldehyde as indicated by the T1/T2 ratios. From a theoretical point of view, the T1/T2 ratio can be seen as equivalent to the energy of surface interaction, which in turn is related to the residence time of molecules on the surface [14]. Considering that molecules adsorbed onto surfaces exhibit modified rotational dynamics and slower translational diffusion, the T1/T2 ratio increases above 1 when the substrate interacts with the catalyst surface [15]. The T1/T2 values collected for benzaldehyde are located within the range 7–25. Differently, for octanal the T1/T2 values are within the range 10–200, thus confirming a stronger interaction than that of benzaldehyde. Similar results were obtained in the case of the bare carbon support: indeed, also in this case, the 2D T1-T2 maps showed consistent differences in the curve shape between n-octanal and benzaldehyde. In particular, the distribution tends more to be continuous or pseudo-continuous with n-octanal in contrast to benzaldehyde, that mainly exhibits few distinct peaks; the number of interaction modes is higher with n-octanal than with benzaldehyde. Since the number of conformations is higher for n-octanal than for benzaldehyde, a possible interpretation is that the probability of a surface interaction when a molecule of n-octanal encounters the surface of the catalyst is also higher. 3.5 Solvent effect: Evaluation of aldehydes adsorption in the presence of p-xylene 3.5.1 Adsorption of p-xylene All the previous experiments were performed using pure substrates. On the contrary, all the experiments performed by 13C High Field NMR have had been done in the presence of a solvent, which was deuterated p-xylene, in agreement with the catalytic reaction performed in p-xylene as solvent [7]. At this point, Low Field NMR analyses results showed a stronger interaction of n-octanal with Pd/C than benzaldehyde, while High Field NMR analyses results, in the presence of p-xylene, showed no specific interaction. Therefore, a more detailed study on the solvent effect was done also by 2D Low Field NMR relaxation. The interaction of p-xylene with the catalyst was investigated first. Fig. 8 shows the 2D T1-T2 map obtained for Pd/C impregnated with p-xylene. The T1 and T2 values are reported in Table 7. The shape of the signal, as well as a T1/T2 ratio of 21.4 (Table 9 ) pointed out a rather strong affinity of p-xylene with the catalyst with only one interaction mode. 3.5.2 Exhibit surface competition between p-xylene and aldehydes Next, the adsorption of benzaldehyde was investigated in the presence of deuterated p-xylene. The latter would be invisible to 1H NMR while exhibiting similar affinity for the surface to that of protonated p-xylene. The comparison of the 2D T1-T2 maps obtained for Pd/C impregnated with pure benzaldehyde (Fig. 9 a) and a solution of benzaldehyde in deuterated p-xylene (1:2) (Fig. 9b) are reported below. The addition of p-xylene led to some visual changes (Fig. 11 a, b). The displacement of the peaks from the central diagonal indicated that there is still an interaction between the benzaldehyde and the catalyst surface, but also a different adsorption behaviour in the presence of the solvent. We therefore assumed that there was competition in adsorption between benzaldehyde and p-xylene. The ‘s1′ and ‘s2′ T1 /T2 values obtained with pure benzaldehyde or benzaldehyde in p-xylene were remarkably different (Table 10 ). This is rather in accordance with the proof of the adsorption of p-xylene (Fig. 8), because if both the molecules adsorbed on the catalyst surface, their simultaneous adsorption is expected to be weaker than that showed by the pure substrates (see Fig. 9 and Fig. 10). Nevertheless, as shown earlier, the competitive adsorption of benzaldehyde and p-xylene did not stop the catalyst’s activity toward benzaldehyde, hydrogenation to benzyl alcohol and toluene. In contrast, the same Pd/C catalyst was not active towards n-octanal hydrogenation to octanol and octane when p-xylene was used as solvent. In this latter case, the solvent strongly affected the apparent catalytic behaviour, as it was possible to increase the substrate conversion from 2 % to 40 % by changing the solvent from p-xylene to n-dodecane [12]. The adsorption of n-octanal was then investigated in the presence of p-xylene and compared with the adsorption of the pure substrate (Fig. 10 a, b) by Low Field NMR analyses. As in the case of benzaldehyde, the effect of the addition of p-xylene on n-octanal adsorption was noted via the 2D T1-T2 map of Pd/C showing a marked change in the shape of the signals. In particular, the intensity of the signal at T2 = 1.1 ms was drastically decreased, while the peak at T2 = 1.9 ms moved slightly up extending more along the diagonal. The reduction in peak intensity and the change of the shape of the peaks were tentatively considered as an indication of a shorter contact time between octanal and the surface of the catalyst. As consequence, it can be hypothesized that octanal would spend less time on the surface of Pd/C in the presence of p-xylene, thus in agreement with catalytic results where p-xylene adversely affected the reaction of octanal hydrogenation on Pd/C catalysts. To confirm the effect of p-xylene on n-octanal adsorption, some NMR analyses were performed using deuterated chloroform (CDCl3) in the role of the solvent. The corresponding NMR 2D T1-T2 maps are shown in Fig. 11. The shape and intensity of the n-octanal signals are barely modified by the presence of chloroform. Despite the influence of CDCl3 on T1/T2 signals is of similar nature as in the case of p-xylene, its influence on the adsorption behavior of n-octanal is sensibly in a lower scale. Therefore, at the end of this experiment we can confirm that the nature of the solvent is playing a fundamental role in determining the interactions between the reactant molecule and the catalyst surface. 4 Theoretical modelling and discussion 4.1 From NMR data to quantified interactions 4.1.1 Theoretical model It is well known that the longitudinal (T1) and transverse (T2) NMR relaxation times are macroscopic observables representative of the microscopic dynamical variables such as translational correlation times and diffusion coefficients. Many theoretical models exist in literature for bulk liquids that relate T1 and T2 to these dynamical variables. However, the situation is more complex for liquids embedded in porous media especially for catalytic materials due to the presence of surface relaxation processes. The situation becomes clearer when measuring the two-dimensional (2D) spin correlation spectrum T2-T1 at a given Larmor frequency (here 20 MHz). Here, an original mixed 2D inversion recovery-FID-CPMG sequence was used, at 20 MHz, which enhances the time scales studied (0.1 ms-3 s) to generate T2-T1 correlation data and the final map has been obtained with an in house 2-D Inverse Laplace Transform program. We have previously proposed parametric relaxation equations for T1 and T2 for liquids at proximity of a solid surface where the source of NMR relaxation comes from the presence of diluted paramagnetic species [4,7]. The proposed model is mainly based on the biphasic fast exchange between the bulk and the surface contributions of the relaxation rates 1/T1 and 1/T2. (1) R 1 , 2 , l i q ω I = R 1 , 2 , b u l k + N S N R 1 , 2 , S u r f ω I . Here R 1 , 2 , b u l k ω I . represents the constant bulk longitudinal or transverse relaxation rates of the liquids which come from the relaxation processes induced by rotational and translational molecular dynamics. In Eq. (1), NS/N represents the surface fraction of the liquid molecules transiently present at pore surfaces: (2) N S N = δ liq S P / V pore . In Eq. (2), δliq is the molecular size of the probe liquid (6.85 Å for n-octanal and 6.07 Å for benzaldehyde), S P is the BET surface area (500 m2/g for the carbon support) and Vpore is the total pore volume (0.84 mL/g). It thus results from Eqs. (1) and (2) that the frequency dependences of R 1 , 2 , l i q ω I are mainly due to the surface contribution R 1 , 2 , S u r f ω I . For the surface relaxation contributions of these rates, the proton-liquid dynamics modulates the intermolecular dipole-dipole interaction between the moving proton of spin I = 1/2 and the fixed S = 1/2 paramagnetic spins of paramagnetic C° radicals at the pore surface. We showed earlier in Fig. 1 that these surface relaxation rates depend mainly on two correlation times: (i) the translational surface diffusion correlation time, τ m , that considers the successive molecular hopping time at the pore surface. This correlation time, τ m , is inversely proportional to the surface diffusion coefficient; (ii) the surface residence time τ S, which is much larger than τ m. In the case of liquid molecules moving transiently on the pore surface in the presence of paramagnetic sources of relaxation such C° radicals, we have shown that the frequency dependences of R 1 , 2 , S u r f ω I are given by the following bilogarithmic expressions [4,7,16]: (3a) R 1 , l i q ω I = R 1 , b u l k liq + μ 0 4 π 2 π 15 δ liq 2 δ ′ liq 2 σ S N S N γ I γ S ℏ 2 S S + 1 τ m 3 l n 1 + ω I 2 τ m 2 ( 1 / A ) 2 + ω I 2 τ m 2 + 7 l n 1 + ω S 2 τ m 2 ( 1 / A ) 2 + ω S 2 τ m 2 (3b) R 2 , l i q ω I = R 2 , b u l k liq + μ 0 4 π 2 2 π 15 δ liq 2 δ ′ liq 2 σ S N S N γ I γ S ℏ 2 S S + 1 τ m 2 log A + 3 4 l n 1 + ω I 2 τ m 2 ( 1 / A ) 2 + ω I 2 τ m 2 + 13 4 l n 1 + ω S 2 τ m 2 ( 1 / A ) 2 + ω S 2 τ m 2 In Eqs. (3a), b), R 1 , 2 b u l k liq are the longitudinal and transverse relaxation rates of the bulk liquids (for benzaldehyde, R 1 , b u l k liq = R 2 , b u l k liq = 1 6 s - 1 ) . These bulk values appears to be frequency independent in the low frequencies range studied. δ’liq is the distance of minimal approach between the moving proton spins (I = 1/2) and the immobile electronic spin (S = 1/2) at the pore surface. We have estimated this distance by a molecular modelling technique giving the theoretical distribution of conformers for these two liquids through the collision cross section CCS. CCS is a projection of molecule conformation to a certain plane approximating the obtained surface by a circle. We found a large distribution of 50 CCS centred around 69 Å2 for n-octanal while one finds a single CCS about 53 Å2 for benzaldehyde. We have thus assumed this distance of minimal approach between I and S spins as the radius R=δ’liq such as CCS = πR 2 and found δ’liq = 4.7 Å and 4.1 Å for octanal and benzaldehyde liquids, respectively. Following Eq. (2), we find the surface fractions N S N = 0.41 a n d 0.16 for the octanal and benzaldehyde molecules, respectively. We have introduced in ref. [16], the dynamical surface affinity by the ratio A = τ S/τ m that represents the average number of molecular steps on the pore surface. This parameter thus represents the local NMR wettability. The surface density of paramagnetic sources of relaxation will be found from the best fit of the experimental data (Fig. 12 ). Finally, ωI/(2π) and ωS/(2π) = 658 ωI/(2π) are the Larmor frequencies of the proton and unpaired electron spins, respectively. 4.1.2 Benefits of low field relaxometry for surface interactions in porous materials In order to better show the main advantages of conducting the 2D T1-T2 at low magnetic fields for probing the surface dynamics of liquids embedded in porous catalytic materials, we have displayed the 2D T1-T2 master curves (Fig. 12) calculated with Eqs. (1- 3a, b) at different Larmor 1H frequencies (10, 20, 50, 100, 200, 500 MHz). The calculated 2D T1-T2 are based on the parameters (τ S, τ m ) determined for benzaldehyde interaction on Pd/C surface (see 4.3.3 for details). For a τ m , each curve indicates where the possible τ S could be observed, and as such the corresponding T1-T2 crosspeak, for their respective Larmor frequencies. We show that the theoretical master curve 2D T1-T2 changes drastically with the frequency. It covers a larger range of observable T1 values at low frequency than at high frequency. It thus results in an easy and direct determination of the surface diffusion correlation time τm and the time of residence τS of liquids at pore surface. One immediately sees that at 10 MHz (blue curve) we have an easy evaluation of these parameters in comparison with the quasi-vertical curve (brown curve) obtained at 500 MHz. This is why our measurements of 2D T1-T2 were made at 20 MHz (orange curve) where these two dynamical parameters τm and τS were easily found by fitting the observed data. We have indicated in the Fig. 12, the bulk contribution which appears to be frequency independent in the low frequency range studied. The benefit of exploring the range of low frequencies is thus to isolate the features (τm and τS) of the surface contribution of T1 and T2 associated with the different processes of molecular surface dynamics. Finally, one should mention that our Low Field T1-T2 2D technique is not limited to catalysts with paramagnetic centers. It can be applied to porous materials that contain specific surface proton species that are different to the protonated studied liquid. In that case we will have T2 < T1 (or even T2≪T1) that allows the acquisition of 2D T1-T2 correlation data similar to the ones presented in Fig. 12. For sure catalyst surfaces doped with ferromagnetic species such as Fe or Ni could be also a good choice for the T1-T2 2D providing that the T1, T2 were not too short for the acquisition of NMR signals. 4.1.3 Example of data fitting Basically, we have two fitting parameters: the translational surface correlation time τ m and the surface density of the paramagnetic sources of relaxation σ S . In Fig. 13 , we have plotted the 2D spin correlation maps T1-T2 for benzaldehyde on Pd/C by varying the surface residence time τ S which a large range from the bulk values (τ S =τ m ) to the very long residence time (τ S ≫πm ). It is also similar to varying the NMR wettability parameter A within a large range from A = 1 (bulk value) to ∞ (fully wetting case). We report in Fig. 13, the approach of finding the best fits of our experimental 2D T1-T2 correlation map in the case of 20 μl of benzaldehyde on Pd/C. According to the very different forms of Eqs. (3a and b) and especially the relative importance of the spectral density at zero frequency for T2 and not on T1, it turns out that σ S will be more impactful on T2 than T1, the right choice of σ S will affect the intensity of the 2D map on the T2 range, while τ m will affect the best T1 range. Applying this method in Fig. 13, we show that the best fit is represented in the middle of the figure with τ m = 23 ns and σ S = 7.7 10 11 C ° / cm 2 . In Fig. 13 the continuous distribution extends from τ S = 23 ns (when the distribution intercepts the bulk value where T1 = T2 to 2.3 ms) to 2.3 ms (when T2 ≪<≪T1). We have repeated this procedure for all our fits. Now, the remaining question is how this fitting procedure relates to the optimal condition for catalysis? For sure, it exists an optimal choice for τ m that controls the surface dynamics necessary to explore the potential largest pore surface. 4.2 Quantification of surface conformational adsorption sites The 2D T1-T2 maps acquired for the various systems investigated in this work showed different overall curve shapes regardless of the substrate. The main difference between benzaldehyde and n-octanal was that the distribution of the peaks was always more continuous, or pseudo-continuous, in the case of n-octanal, in contrast to benzaldehyde which exhibited mainly separate peaks. This phenomenon is related to the number of conformational adsorption sites of these two substrates on the catalyst surface, which can be calculated. The calculations have been performed to generate all possible conformers and after which their collision cross section (CCS), either for benzaldehyde or for n-octanal, are determined. The CCS is a projection of the molecule conformation to a certain plane approximating the obtained surface by a circle. Benzaldehyde has only one conformer, with a CCS of 52.93 Å2 and a diameter of 8.21 Å, which confirms that benzaldehyde is a rather rigid molecule. On the contrary, octanal provides 50 conformers with an average CCS of 69.57 Å2 and a diameter of 9.41 Å which is in agreement with the continuous behavior of n-octanal peaks (Fig. 11). 4.3 Application of theoretical model to NMR data The signals in the 2D maps can be connected by a continuous universal line that can be used to correlate all the adsorption sites characterized individually by the residence correlation time τS that varies continuously along this line. The model of a unique adsorption curve that can link all the peaks can be used here to elucidate the difference between the samples highlighted by Low Field NMR relaxation analyses. 4.3.1 Adsorption model and parameters According to the theory described above on Eqs. (1-3a, b), different peaks in the T1-T2 map of the molecule can be related to some specific parameters such as the total surface residence time (τs) and translational surface diffusion time (τm), provided the presence of randomly distributed paramagnetic ions. In the case of the carbon support, atomic C● radicals are usually present in the system. The NMR wettability can then be ascribed to the parameter A = τs/τm (Fig. 13). 4.3.2 Fitting of NMR data from impregnation on carbon support Fig. 14 shows the best model fits of the data obtained from the adsorption tests of 20, 50 and 100 µl of benzaldehyde on carbon support. For low T1, the behaviour is close to a quasi-solid effect or very slow motions on the surface (T1 constant and T2 variable (T2≪T1)). For large T1, the dominant behaviour of benzaldehyde is one of a confined liquid (T1 proportional to T2 where T1 > T2). Then, in Fig. 15 b the simulation of the n-octanal adsorption behaviour is reported (referring to the corresponding 2D T1-T2 map - Fig. 15a). The theoretical calculation showed a larger distribution of the time of residence for n-octanal than benzaldehyde (Figs. 13, 14), thus showing a higher affinity of n-octanal for the surface of carbon. 4.3.3 Fitting of NMR data from impregnation of Pd/C As done for the carbon support, the theoretical simulation was performed for benzaldehyde on Pd/C (Fig. 16 ) and n-octanal on Pd/C (Fig. 17 ). The best fits obtained by the theoretical model for Pd/C impregnated with either n-octanal (50 µl) or benzaldehyde (50 µl) are reported in Fig. 18 , for a better comparison. The two fits of the experimental 2D plots (Fig. 18) have been obtained considering an identical surface area of Pd/C (SP, NMR = 500 m2/g) as bare carbon. The correlation times were τ m = 25 ns for n-octanal and 23 ns for benzaldehyde liquids. The points fitted for n-octanal are more continuously dispersed than those related to benzaldehyde, which were instead quite isolated. According to this molecular modelling technique and the best fits obtained in Fig. 18, we can interpret the different curve shapes observed for the two T1-T2 data as coming from very large differences of the wettability distribution of these two liquids on pore surfaces. 4.3.4 Fitting of p-xylene influence on affinity Through data fitting it possible to quantify the effect of p-xylene on the affinity of the molecular probe for the surface of the catalyst. We illustrate this with the data of n-octanal and Pd/C in Fig. 19 . The results of the fittings showed that the τm increases in the presence of p-xylene, precisely from 25 to 58 ns. This indicates a serious slowing down of the motion of n-octanal on the surface of Pd/C when p-xylene is present. Therefore, the 2D NMR relaxation concludes to a slowing down of the liquid at surface in presence of p-xylene, which means less visiting sites on surface. These results agree strongly with the NMR adsorption analyses of these systems performed in High Field [1]: the crucial role of the solvent in changing the adsorption behaviour of a molecule on the surface of an heterogeneous catalyst is confirmed. This establishes the complementarity of 1H Low Field NMR and 13C High Field NMR which for the first time were applied in a detailed study of the dynamics between substrates, catalysts and reaction media that are key in many heterogeneous catalytic processes. 5 Conclusion The combination of High Field NMR measurements [1] with the present results on Low Field 2D NMR relaxation confirmed the possibility to extract information on local molecular dynamics (High Field) and 2D surface dynamics (Low Field). We demonstrated this for the complex system of aldehyde hydrogenation on Pd/C catalysts in the presence of p-xylene as a solvent. In fact, 2D Low Field 1H NMR relaxation is sensitive to the environment of the reactant molecules, being a unique source of relaxation by the fluctuation of the dipole–dipole interaction between the immobile paramagnetic species on surfaces and the translational diffusion of the protonated molecule; therefore, it gives unambiguous information on the surface dynamics of the molecule. On the other hand, in addition to the structural insights, 13C High Field NMR is sensitive to the orientation/ mobility in the static field of the molecule. As a consequence, the variation of the relaxation times T1s and T2s can be assumed as a proof of a preferred orientation or restricted mobility. A preferred orientation could result from the interaction with the surface; however, an absence of a preferred orientation is not unequivocally an indication of non-interaction. In other words, the High Field T1 invariancy when the catalyst is present cannot be always considered as an absence of interaction of the molecule with the catalyst surface (pre-requisite for activity). The convergence of a universal modelling of 2D NMR relaxation T1-T2 experiments allows finding dynamical parameters giving a comprehensive understanding of the behaviours of different molecular liquids at pore surfaces. We can mention that our method could be also useful for studying the dynamics of confined ionic liquids as for example with lithium in solid batteries. For these reasons, the complementary study of Low- and High Field NMR relaxometry to unravel the role of the reactant-catalyst interaction in heterogeneous catalysis can be considered an exceptional new way of characterization and investigation study. In 13C High Field NMR relaxometry the T1ads/T1bulk measurements can provide a guide to the selection of appropriate reaction conditions for improving catalytic activity, for example indicating how the solvent affects the interaction between the substrates and the active catalytic surface; studies by 1H Low Field NMR relaxometry can fine-tune the technique in an attempt to disentangle chemical from physical adsorption thus detailing the role of the support material. coredata.dc:description: This work aims to disclose the support-substrate interaction and surface dynamics in heterogeneous catalysis by an original Low Field 2D NMR relaxation in complement to previous High Field NMR relaxometry. The combination of High Field NMR measurements with the new Low Field 2D NMR results presented in this work confirmed the possibility to extract information on local molecular dynamics and 2D surface dynamics for the complex system of aldehyde hydrogenation on Pd/C catalysts in the presence of a solvent. In particular, here multidimensional Low Field (2D) 1H nuclear magnetic relaxation experiments (T1-T2) have been used to characterize noninvasively the dynamical properties of benzaldehyde, octanal and p-xylene at surfaces of Pd-supported on carbon catalysts. 2D Low Field 1H NMR relaxation is sensitive to the environment of the reactant molecules and gives unambiguous information on the surface dynamics of the molecule; the association with previous 13C NMR relaxation at High Field s allows comparison between molecular orientations and local surface dynamics at surface of catalysts. In heterogeneous catalysis these new experimental and theoretical multiscale approaches link interfacial molecular dynamics and interaction with catalytic materials. This point is critical for disentangle chemical from physical reactant adsorption and deepening the role of the support material and its physical features in catalytic processes.
coredata.dc:title: Low‐field 2D NMR relaxometry to disclose the support-substrate interaction and surface dynamics in heterogeneous catalysis: A novel and complementary view to high field NMR relaxometry
